Southwest Florida's top panther experts descended on Caribbean Gardens Zoo in Naples on Saturday to bring the plight of the endangered species to the people. As part of Save the Panther Day, organizers from Friends of the Florida Panther and wildlife officials from the Florida Panther National Wildlife Refuge spent the day at the zoo educating people about the panther and its habitat.

Larry Richardson, a wildlife biologist working at the refuge, demonstrated how they track panthers using radio collars. He also explained the challenges faced by panthers due to habitat loss and gave positive news that there are still approximately 100 panthers remaining in southern Florida.

To join

What: Friends of the Florida Panther

Cost: $15 for a family, $10 for an individual

Where: Friends of the Florida Panther Refuge, Attn. Treasurer c/o US Fish & Wildlife Service 3860 Tollgate Blvd. Suite 3000, Naples, FL 34114.

"I was very interested just to know that the population has doubled," said Anita Zatz of Fort Lauderdale.

About a decade ago, biologists estimated there were between 30 to 50 panthers; now they put the figure at around 100.

Norma Dayton of Venice expressed encouragement after hearing that the fences surrounding Alligator Alley are helping.
